coredata.dc:title: Discovery of new benzensulfonamide derivatives as tripedal STAT3 inhibitors

All rights reserved.Elsevier Masson SAS.Guo, JianpengYu, WenyingCai, GuipingZhang, WendaLi, ShanshanZhu, JiawenSong, DongmeiKong, Lingyi Persistent activated STAT3 has a striking correlation with cancer development and inhibition of STAT3 signaling pathway is a novel therapeutic way for human cancers. Among STAT family, STAT1 and STAT3 play opposite roles in tumorigenesis. However, the discovery of selective STAT3 inhibitors is still challenging to date. In this study, a series of small-molecular (MW < 500) benzensulfanilamide derivatives were designed to selectively suppress STAT3 activation for anti-cancer treatment. The most potent compound 11 inhibited both overexpressed and IL-6 induced STAT3 phosphorylation, whereas 11 displayed little effect on the phosphorylation of other STAT isoforms STAT1, STAT5, demonstrating 11 was a selective STAT3 inhibitor. Meanwhile, 11 dismissed STAT3 DNA binding activity and colony formation. In addition, 11 elevated the ROS level and induced apoptosis of cancer cells. Furthermore, 11 effectively suppressed tumor growth in an in vivo mouse-xenograft model. 0falsefalseAntitumor activitySulfonamideSelectivityStructure-based drug designSTAT3 phosphorylationApoptosis

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Design strategy. The skeleton of 36 was colored purple. 11 was shown in stick-ball and its skeleton was colored turquoise blue. The surface of SH2 domain was colored according to element property. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.)

Docking model of compounds with sulfanilamide fragment at ortho-, meta- and para-position binding to the STAT3 SH2 domain (PDB: 1BG1) generated by AutoDock4.2. STAT3 protein was represented as white ribbon. The key residues were shown. Hydrogen bonds were represented by green dashes. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.)

Docking model of 11 binding to the STAT3 SH2 domain (PDB: 1BG1) generated by AutoDock4.2. (A) 11 was colored by atom type. The surface of SH2 domain was colored according to element property. (B) STAT3 protein was represented as white ribbon. The key residues were shown. Hydrogen bonds were represented by green dashes. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.)

Compound 11 inhibited STAT3 activation and didn't inhibit STAT1 and STAT5 phosphorylation. (A) The effect of compound 11 on p-STAT3 (Y705), STAT3, p-STAT1 (Y701), STAT1, p-STAT5 (Y694) and STAT5 protein expression by western blot analysis using GAPDH as a control. (B) Compound 11 and 36 inhibited STAT3 and STAT1 phosphorylation in HCT-116 cells at 10 μM for 20 h by western blot analysis. (C) Compound 11 inhibited STAT3 phosphorylation induced by IL-6 in HCT-116 cells by western blot analysis. (D) EMSA analysis of nuclear extracts of equal total protein containing activated STAT3 from HCT-116 cells treated with compound 11 for 20 h after incubation with hSIE probe that binds STAT3.

Compound 11 affected the expressions of STAT3-regulated proteins. Western blot analysis of p-Src, Src, p-Erk, Erk, Bcl-2 and Cyclin D1 levels in whole-cell lysates of equal total protein prepared from HCT-116 cells treated with compound 11 for 20 h.

Compound 11 induced tumor cells apoptosis in vitro. (A) The Annexin V/7-AAD staining assay was used to analyze the compound 11 induced apoptosis in HCT-116 cells detected by flow cytometry. (B) Percent of HCT-116 cells undergoing apoptosis after treatment with 11 for 20 h. Data are the mean value ± SD obtained from three independent experiments. (C) Western blot analysis with antibodies specific for Caspase-3, Cleaved Caspase-3, Caspase-7, Cleaved Caspase-7, Caspase-9, Cleaved Caspase-9 and the house keeping protein GAPDH in HCT-116 cells incubated with compound 11 for 20 h ***p < 0.001, **p < 0.01.

Compound 11 induced ROS generation. (A) 11 increased ROS generation measured by DCFH-DA staining and analyzed by flow cytometry. (B) Mean value fluorescence intensity of HCT-116 cells after treatment with 11 for 20 h ***p < 0.001, **p < 0.01.
Compound 11 inhibited cancer cells proliferation in vitro. Colony forming assay was implemented to assess the anti-proliferative activity of the compound 11 with respect to HCT-116 cells.

Compound 11 inhibited the growth of human sarcoma xenograft tumors in vivo. (A) Anatomical nude mice's tumor tissue untreated or treated with 11 (10 and 20 mg/kg). (B) Inhibition percentage of mice's tumor tissues upon treatment of 11 (10 and 20 mg/kg). (C) The growing curves of mice's tumor volume. (D) The growing curves of mice's body weight. (E) Western blot analysis of p-STAT3 (Y705) and STAT3 levels in tumor tissues prepared from control or mice treated with 11 (10 and 20 mg/kg). ***p < 0.001, **p < 0.01.

Synthesis of series A-C compounds.Reagents and conditions: (a) (i) AcOH, 4 Å molecular sieves, DCM, 30 min; (ii) Na(OAc)3BH3, rt, overnight; (b) K2CO3, MeCN, reflux, 10 h; (c) K2CO3, MeCN, reflux, overnight.
Antiproliferative activity of the designed compounds and the control compound 36.

ce:table-footnote.ce:label: a
ce:table-footnote.ce:note-para: The inhibitory effects of the compounds on the proliferation of HCT-116 cell line were determined by the MTT assay. SD: standard deviation, all experiments were independently performed at least three times.

head.ce:title: Discovery of new benzensulfonamide derivatives as tripedal STAT3 inhibitors

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Bioactive Natural Product Research and State Key Laboratory of Natural Medicines, China Pharmaceutical University, 24 Tong Jia Xiang, Nanjing, 210009, People's Republic of China

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Bioactive Natural Product Research and State Key Laboratory of Natural Medicines

ce:footnote.ce:note-para: Both authors contributed equally to this paper.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Persistent activated STAT3 has a striking correlation with cancer development and inhibition of STAT3 signaling pathway is a novel therapeutic way for human cancers. Among STAT family, STAT1 and STAT3 play opposite roles in tumorigenesis. However, the discovery of selective STAT3 inhibitors is still challenging to date. In this study, a series of small-molecular (MW < 500) benzensulfanilamide derivatives were designed to selectively suppress STAT3 activation for anti-cancer treatment. The most potent compound 11 inhibited both overexpressed and IL-6 induced STAT3 phosphorylation, whereas 11 displayed little effect on the phosphorylation of other STAT isoforms STAT1, STAT5, demonstrating 11 was a selective STAT3 inhibitor. Meanwhile, 11 dismissed STAT3 DNA binding activity and colony formation. In addition, 11 elevated the ROS level and induced apoptosis of cancer cells. Furthermore, 11 effectively suppressed tumor growth in an in vivo mouse-xenograft model.

Compound 11 selectively inhibited STAT3 activation to exert antitumor activity.
Image 1

ce:keyword.ce:text: signal transducer and activator of transcription

ce:section.ce:para: Signal transducer and activator of transcription 3 (STAT3) is persistently overexpressed in various tumor cell lines and STAT3 signaling pathway is a critical cancer causing module, indicating STAT3 is an important target for anti-tumor drug design [1–4].

STAT3 monomer can be phosphorylated at tyrosine residue (Tyr705) by growth factor receptor tyrosine kinases, Janus kinases, or the Src family kinases [5,6]. Two phosphorylated STAT3 form activated homo-dimeric transcription factor complex via a reciprocal pTyr-SH2 domain interaction. The p-STAT3 dimers would then translocate to the nucleus, bind to specific DNA fragments, induce target gene expression, and finally cause cellular anti-apoptosis, proliferation, and tumor invasion [5,7–10].

Among STAT protein family, STAT1, STAT3 and STAT5 are correlated with tumor progression [11]. Opposite to carcinogenic effect of STAT3 and STAT5, STAT1 exerts anti-tumor function via anti-proliferative and pro-apoptotic activities in tumor cells [12]. A preeminent STAT3 inhibitor should inhibit STAT3 activation with good selectivity against STAT1.

The crystal structure of STAT3 SH2 domain has been resolved and it has three contiguous binding subpockets for drug targeting, including pTyr705 site, Leu706 site and side pocket [13–16]. STAT3 inhibitors, directly targeting the SH2 domain, have been recently developed, including small peptides, peptidomimetics, and non-peptidic small molecules [4,17,18]. Compared with other inhibitors, nonpeptidic small-molecule STAT3 inhibitors with good cell permeability, high bioavailability and target specificity represent great potential to be developed as clinical agents (Fig. 1 ) [19–28].

Most reported STAT3 inhibitors can only bind to two pockets of SH2 domain. To improve STAT3-inhibitory activity and binding affinity, only few tripedal SH2 domain inhibitors are developed as drug candidates. The most promising compound is BP-1-102 (36), discovered by James Turkson research group, which is entering advanced clinical trials [25]. Some other tripedal STAT3 inhibitors were also reported by their group [5–7,23–25]. However, compared with STAT3 inhibitors binding to two pockets, the anti-tumor activity of 36 is moderate. Besides, STAT isoform selectivity is still poor [7]. Moreover, these tripedal inhibitors with high molecular weight over 500, which violates the Lipinski's rule of five, limited its drug likeness. Our group has been studying on STAT3 inhibitors for many years and made some progress in this field [20,21,29–31]. We found that STAT3 inhibitors containing sulfanilamide portion possessed excellent anti-cancer activity and STAT3 selectivity, such as LLL12 (30), LY-5 (31) and LY-17 (32) [19–21]. In this study, Structure-based drug design approach was used to identify a series of sulfanilamide based tripedal STAT3 inhibitors with MW < 500, which showed promising activity against cancer and better selectivity among STAT isoforms than other tripedal STAT3 inhibitors (Fig. 2 ).

According to the X-ray structure of STAT3 SH2 domain (PDB code 1BG1), the main pTyr705 binding site is polar, the Leu706 and the side pocket sites are hydrophobic [32]. Based on the above structural analysis, we used a sulfanilamide fragment as a hydrogen bond receptor to form hydrogen bonding with residue Arg609 in the pTyr705 binding site, while two other nonpolar segments were designed to bind to the other two binding spots of SH2 domain. Then, only a nitrogen atom was used to connect the three moieties for targeting the three pockets respectively. The position of sulfanilamide was determined by docking experiments. As shown in Fig. 3 , in comparison with para-position, meta-position was more suitable for all three pockets and the distance of hydrogen bond with Arg609 residues for binding to pTyr705 site was shorter. So we put the sulfanilamide fragment at meta-position to occupy the essential pTyr705 binding site. Whereas, the sulfanilamide group couldn't form a hydrogen bond at ortho-position.

To better fitting the side pocket, we tried various nonpolar segments in side pocket yielding compounds 2–16. In order to obtain suitable fragment for Leu706 binding site, we placed aniline derivatives in Leu706 site, which generated a series of compounds 18–25. In addition, we synthesized compounds 26–29 whose sulfanilamide group was linked with a protective benzyl group, thus the hydrogen bonds between compounds and Arg609 in STAT3 protein might be destroyed. The synthetic pathways of designed compounds were described in Scheme 1 .

The in vitro antitumor activity of all compounds were evaluated against human colonic carcinoma HCT-116 via MTT assay using compound 36 as a positive control. The IC50 values of the benzensulfanilamide derivatives on HCT-116 cell line were determined and the results were illustrated in Table 1 . Most of these compounds showed better activity than the positive control excluding the compounds with protected sulfanilamide group. Especially, compounds 11 (IC50 = 6.65 μM for HCT-116 cell line) displayed the most potent inhibitory activity against tumor cell proliferation among all.

The SAR for the benzyl groups occupying the side pocket was summarized as follows. Substituent at the meta-position showed better inhibitory activity than at the ortho- or para-position, comparing compounds 4 with 3 and 5, 7 with 6 and 8 or 13 with 12 and 14. The stronger electron-withdrawing substitutes at meta-position had higher antitumor activities, such as Br < Cl < F < CF3 for compounds 4, 7, 13, 15. Thus, compound 11 possessing perfluorobenzene was most potent among all compounds in Series A. So we chose perfluorobenzene to occupy the side pocket and further tried different aniline groups fitting to the Leu706 site to generate Series B. Compounds 20, 22, 23, 24 and 25 (with substitution group at para-position) exhibited higher inhibitory activity than compounds 18, 19 and 21 (with substituent at the meta-position), indicating the substitution group should be located at the para-position for the Leu706 site. There was no obvious difference between the electron-donating and electron-withdrawing substituent. No or poor affinity of compounds in Series C indicated that the free sulfanilamide group was the most vital pharmacophore for anti-cancer activity.

To determine whether the designed compounds docked to the binding sites of the STAT3 protein, the potential binding modes of the most potent compound 11 with the STAT3 SH2 domain were predicted by docking experiments. As shown in Fig. 4 , 11 was docked to the hot spots of the SH2 domain, with a binding energy of −6.9 kcal/mol. The phenylsulfonamide fragment bound to the key pY705 pocket while the perfluorobenzene fragment occupied the side pocket and the isopropyl benzene fragment sat in the Leu706 subpocket. 11 bound to STAT3 SH2 via a hydrogen bond interaction with Arg609 residues (distance = 2.038 Å). Overall, the docking result confirmed our design and gained further understanding of the structure-activity relationship.

To examine whether the mechanism of compound 11 is on STAT3 signaling pathway, a western blot assay was performed to investigate the expression level of phosphorylated STAT3 (p-STAT3) and total STAT3 after HCT-116 cells were incubated with 11 (4–12 μM) for 20 h. As shown in Fig. 5 A, 11 markedly suppressed STAT3 phosphorylation in a dose-dependent manner with little effect on total STAT3, indicating the decrease of p-STAT3 (Y705) was not related with the reduction of total STAT3. While, 11 showed better inhibition for the phosphorylated STAT3 level than 36 at 10 μM for 20 h (Fig. 5B).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Compound 11 inhibited interleukin-6 (IL-6) induced STAT3 phosphorylation
ce:section.ce:para: IL-6, a cytokine, can induce STAT3 activation [33]. To determine whether compound 11 is capable of inhibiting IL-6 induced STAT3 phosphorylation, HCT-116 cells were serum starved overnight, and then were left untreated or were treated with 11 (4–12 μM). After 10 h, the level of p-STAT3 (Y705) was increased by IL-6, which could be suppressed by 11 in a dose-dependent manner (Fig. 5C).

To further study the inhibition of STAT3 by compound 11, we performed electrophoretic mobility shift assay (EMSA) to examine the inhibition of STAT3:STAT3 DNA-binding activity. HCT-116 cancer cells at 50% confluence were treated with 11 (4–12 μM) or DMSO for 20 h. Then cells were harvested and nuclear extracts were obtained followed by incubating with hSIE probe, and then EMSA assay was performed. The capability of STAT3 binding DNA was significantly decreased when cells were treated with 11 (Fig. 5D).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Selectivity of compound 11 among STAT isoforms
ce:section.ce:para: To investigate the selectivity of compound 11 among STAT isoforms, we further performed western blot assays to investigate the effects of 11 on STAT1 and STAT5 phosphorylation. As shown in Figs. 5A, 11 had little influence on the level of p-STAT1 (Y701) and p-STAT5 (Y694). In addition, we compared 11 with 36 in STAT1 phosphorylation. HCT-116 cells were exposed to 11 and 36 respectively at 10 μM for 20 h, then were harvested and carried out by immunoblotting assay. 11 had little inhibition on STAT1 while 36 inhibited phosphorylation of STAT1 (Fig. 5B). All these results demonstrated that 11 was a selective STAT3 inhibitor.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Compound 11 affected the expression of STAT3 related proteins
ce:section.ce:para: To investigate whether upstream kinases (such as Src) or bypass kinases (such as Erk1/2) are involved in compound 11 mediated STAT3 inactivation, we examined the effects of 11 on the phosphorylation of Src, Erk1/2 by immunoblotting analysis. The result suggested 11 had little or no effect on upstream tyrosine kinase p-Src and didn't inhibit p-Erk1/2. To further study the impact of 11 on the inhibition of STAT3, we examined the expression levels of the downstream proteins, such as Cyclin D1 and Bcl-2. As shown in Fig. 6 , 11 dose-dependently suppressed the expression of Cyclin D1 and Bcl-2.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Compound 11 induced apoptosis in cancer cells
ce:section.ce:para: Compound 11 could down-regulate the expression of STAT3-related protein Bcl-2, which is involved in anti-apoptosis and caspase dependent pathway [34]. So we speculated that the anti-tumor potency of 11 might be consistent with the induction of apoptosis. To verify this, an Annexin V/7-AAD staining assay was performed to quantify the apoptotic effect of 11 in cancer cells. As shown in Fig. 7 A and B, the result showed that a large percentage of HCT-116 cells underwent dose-dependent apoptosis after 11 incubation. To further study the mechanism of 11 for cell apoptosis, we evaluated the levels of caspase-related proteins by western blots. The cleavage levels of caspase-3/7/9 were increased in a dose dependent manner treated by 11 (Fig. 5C).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Compound 11 induced the ROS generation in cancer cells
ce:section.ce:para: There is ample evidence that ROS is involved in inducing cell apoptosis [35]. We continued to evaluate ROS production affected by 11 in cancer cells. HCT-116 cells were treated with 11 in various concentrations for 20 h, followed by incubating with 2′,7′-dichloro-fluorescein diacetate (DCFH-DA) probe before measuring the fluorescence intensity of 2′,7′-dichloro-fluorescein (DCF) by flow cytometry. The level of ROS was increased treated with 11 ( Fig. 8 A and B), indicating 11 induced ROS production in HCT-116 cells.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Compound 11 reduced colony formation in vitro
ce:section.ce:para: To further investigate whether compound 11 treatment might inhibit proliferation, we performed colony formation assay. We treated HCT-116 cells with 11 for 20 h. After treatment, viable cells were cultured in fresh medium without 11 for 2 weeks. As shown in Fig. 9 , 11 dose-dependently inhibited the proliferation of HCT-116 cells.

A mouse-xenograft model was established to evaluate the antitumor effect of compound 11 in vivo. Human colon cancer HCT-116 was implanted into the hind flank of female nude mice and allowed to establish sizeable tumor. After the solid tumors development, the mice were randomized and divided into three groups consisting of 6 mice/group. As shown in Fig. 10 , 11 dramatically inhibited tumor weight (41.30% decrease at 10 mg/kg, 56.84% decrease at 20 mg/kg) and volume (35.69% decrease at 10 mg/kg, 58.12% decrease at 20 mg/kg). Western blot results showed that 11 inhibited the level of p-STAT3 in tumor tissue in vivo. There is no significant change in body weight, indicating 11 showed no obvious signs of toxicity. Moreover, we performed acute toxicity test on ICR mice to further evaluate the safety profile of 11. No sign of toxicity was observed even at 80 mg/kg dose.

Taken together, a series of benzensulfanilamide derivatives were designed and synthesized as novel STAT3 inhibitors that exhibit promising antitumor activity in vitro and in vivo. Our designed compounds were characterized as lower molecular weight (less than 500) and better selectivity, indicating improved drug likeness comparing to the known tripedal STAT3 inhibitors, represented by the most potent compound 11. Molecular docking studies demonstrated 11 could tightly bind to STAT3 SH2 domain and further provided a rationale for structure-activity relationship. 11 inhibited STAT3 phosphorylation, IL-6 induced STAT3 phosphorylation, STAT3 binding activity and the expression of downstream proteins while had little impact on the phosphorylation of other STAT isoforms (STAT1, STAT5) and upstream kinase (Src). 11 inhibited the colony formation of cancer cells and induced the apoptosis. Furthermore, 11 significantly suppressed human colon cancer HCT-116 xenograft tumor growth in vivo. On the basic of our findings, the antiproliferative and proapoptotic effects of 11 is owning to its ability to inhibit STAT3 phosphorylation. In summary, 11 possessed good selectivity on p-STAT3 among other STAT isoforms and potent anti-tumor activity, which might be a potential antitumor drug.

The solvents and reagents were purchased from commercial suppliers and used without further purification. Reaction progress was monitored using analytical thin layer chromatography (TLC) on precoated silica gel GF254 plates (Qingdao Haiyang Chemical Plant, Qingdao, China) plates and the spots were detected under UV light (254 nm). Column chromatography was performed on silica gel (90–150 μM; Qingdao Marine Chemical Inc.) Melting points were measured on an XT-4 micromelting point instrument and uncorrected. 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra were measured on a Bruker ACF-500 spectrometer at 25 °C and referenced to TMS. Chemical shifts are reported in ppm (δ) using the residual solvent line as internal standard. Mass spectra were obtained on a MS Agilent 1l00 Series LC/MSD Trap mass spectrometer (ESI-MS) and a Mariner ESI-TOF spectrometer (HRESI-MS), respectively. All of the synthetic derivatives and compounds purchased were obtained with >96.0% purity as determined by HPLC (UV detection at 280 nm).

ce:section.ce:section-title: General procedure for the synthesis of 1 and 17
ce:section.ce:para: To a solution of 3-aminobenzenesulfonamide (1.0 equiv) and acetic acid (1.2 equiv) stirred in anhydrous dichloromethane (0.1 M) with 4 Å molecular sieves was added aldehyde (1.2 equiv). The solution was then stirred for 30 min. Next, Na(OAc)3BH3 (2.0 equiv) was added in portions and then reaction allowed to stir at room temperature overnight. When TLC indicated the reaction was complete, the reaction was filtered and the solution was concentrated, loaded on silica gel, and purified by flash column chromatography with petroleum/ethyl acetate as eluent to give 1 and 17.

ce:section.ce:section-title: General procedure for the synthesis of 2–16 and 18–25
ce:section.ce:para: A mixture of 1 or 17 (1.0 equiv) and K2CO3 (1.5 equiv) in acetonitrile (0.1 M) was stirred at room temperature for 30 min. The benzyl halide (1.2 equiv) was added and the mixture was stirred and refluxed for 8 h. After the mixture was cooled, the inorganic salts was filtered and washed with dichloromethane. The filtrate was evaporated and the residue was purified by flash column chromatography (petroleum/ethyl acetate) to give the title compounds 2–16 and 18–25.

ce:section.ce:section-title: General procedure for the synthesis of 26–29
ce:section.ce:para: A mixture of 1 or 17 (1.0 equiv) and K2CO3 (2.0 equiv) in acetonitrile (0.1 M) was stirred at room temperature for 30 min. The benzyl halide (2.5 equiv) was added and the mixture was stirred and refluxed overnight. After the mixture was cooled, the inorganic salts was filtered and washed with dichloromethane. The filtrate was evaporated and the residue was purified by flash column chromatography (petroleum/ethyl acetate) to give the compounds 26–29.

Docking studies were performed with computational docking program AutoDock4.2. Compounds were docked using the Lamarckian Genetic Algorithm. The Schrodinger software was employed to prepare the macromolecule and ligand. Gasteiger charges were assigned to the ligands by AutoDockTools. AutoGrid maps were further precomputed for all atom types in the ligand set. After completing 10 million energy evaluations, the root-mean-square deviation threshold was set as 2.0 Å and all the conformations of the ligands in the binding pocket of the macromolecule were clustered. The lowest energy clusters were identified and binding energies were evaluated.

Cancer cell line human colonic carcinoma HCT-116 was purchased from the Cell Bank of Shanghai Institute of Biochemistry and Cell Biology, Chinese Academy of Sciences (Shanghai, China). HCT-116 cells were cultured in Dulbecco modified Eagle medium (DMEM) plus 10% (vol/vol) fetal bovine serum (FBS), 50 mg/ml penicillin and 50 mg/ml streptomycin. Both cell lines were incubated at 37 °C in a humidified atmosphere containing 5% CO2.

Cells (HCT116) were seeded in 96-well plates at a density of 3500–6000 cells per well. The cells were incubated at 37 °C overnight in a humidified 5% CO2 incubator. After medium removal, different concentrations of test compounds were added in triplicate to the plates in 200 μL fresh mediums, the plates were incubated at 37 °C for 48 h. The percentage of DMSO in the medium not exceeded 0.1% 3-(4, 5-Dimethylthiazolyl)-2, 5-diphenyltetrazoliumbromide (MTT) was added to evaluate cell viability. The absorbance was measured at 570 nm using a microplate reader (Spectramax Plus 384, Molecular Devices, Sunnyvale, CA, USA). The cytotoxic activity was expressed as the IC50 values. All experiments were conducted in triplicate and repeated more than three times.

HCT-116 cells were incubated with various concentrations of compound 11 or 0.1% DMSO for 20 h. Harvested after trypsinisation, cells were treated with 1 × RIPA lysis buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.4, 150 mM NaCl, 0.25% deoxycholic acid, 1% NP-40, 1 mM EDTA and protease inhibitors PMSF) (Amresco, Solon, USA) to extract the total proteins. An aliquot of proteins from the total cell lysates (40–80 μg per lane) was separated by sodium dodecyl sulfate (8% or 10%) polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE, BioRad Laboratories, Hercules, CA), wet-transferred to PVDF membrane (BioRad Laboratories, Hercules, CA) and blotted with primary antibodies specific for STAT1, p-STAT1 (Y701), STAT3, p-STAT3 (Y705), STAT5, p-STAT5 (Y694), Src, p-Src, Erk1/2, p-Erk1/2, Bcl-2, Cyclin D1, Caspase-3, Cleaved Caspase-3, Caspase-7, Cleaved Caspase-7, Caspase-9, Cleaved Caspase-9 and GAPDH, probed with secondary isotype specific antibodies tagged with horseradish peroxidase (Cell Signaling Technology). Bound immunocomplexes were detected using a ChemiDOC™ XRS + system (BioRad Laboratories, Hercules, CA).

HCT-116 cells were seeded in 6-well plates and allowed to adhere overnight. The following night, the cells were serum starved. The cells were then left untreated or were treated with compound 11 or DMSO. After 10 h, the untreated and 11 treated cells were stimulated by IL-6 (25 ng/ml). The cells were harvested at 30 min and analyzed by Western blot.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Nuclear extract preparation and gel shift assays
ce:section.ce:para: HCT-116 cells at 45%–55% confluence were treated with compound 11 or DMSO in the presence of 10% FBS for 20 h. The cells were harvested and nuclear extract preparations and EMSA analysis were carried out as previously described. The 32P labeled oligonucleotide hSIE probe was used to bind STAT3.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Annexin V-APC/7-AAD double staining to detect apoptosis
ce:section.ce:para: HCT-116 cells growing in the logarithmic phase were trypsinized and seeded into a 6-well plate. After attach to the plate, cells were treated with compound 11 for 20 h, 0.25% trypsin (without EDTA) was used to trypsinize and gather the cells. The cells were washed twice with phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) (centrifugation at 2000 rpm, 5 min) and collected. The cells were then resuspended in 500 μL of binding buffer. After 5 μL of Annexin V-APC was added and mixed well, 5 μL of 7-AAD was added and mixed well. After 15 min of incubation, a flow cytometer (FACSCalibur; Becton-Dickinson, USA) was used to detect apoptosis.

The level of intracellular ROS was measured by using the ROS-sensitive dye, 2′, 7′-dichloro-fluorescein diacetate (DCFH-DA), as a probe. In brief, HCT-116 cells were seeded in six-well plates at 3 × 105 cells/well, culturing in the presence or absence of various concentrations of compound 11 for additional 20 h, and then washed three times and incubated with final concentration of 10 μM DCFH-DA for 30 min at 37 °C in the dark. After incubation, cells were washed three times and harvested in free-serum medium. The fluorescence of 2′, 7′-dichlorofluorescein (DCF) was detected by flow cytometry (488 nm excitation and 525 nm emission filters) using BD Accuri C6 flow cytometer (Becton & Dickinson Company, Franklin Lakes, NJ, USA). Data were processed using cell quest software (Becton & Dickinson Company, Franklin Lakes, NJ).

Cells were cultured at 500 cells per well in 6-well plate with regular growth medium. Cells were treated by vehicle, and compound 11 at various concentrations on the following day for 20 h. And Cells were allowed to grow for 2 weeks until the colonies were visible. Crystal violet solution (Sigma, St. Louis, MO, USA) was used to stain the colonies for 4 h.

Six-week-old female nude mice, of Specified Pathogens Free (SPF) grade, were purchased from Model Animal Research Center of Nanjing University (Nanjing, China). Nude mice were injected in the right flank area with 5 × 106 human colon cancer HCT-116 cells in 100 μL of PBS. After 5–10 days, tumors with a diameter of 3 mm were established. The mice were divided randomly into three groups (6 mice/group) and intraperitoneally administered with compound 11 (10 or 20 mg/kg) or vehicle daily and monitored every 2 or 3 days. Tumor growth was determined by Tumor volume, which was calculated according to formula V = 0.52 × a 2 × b (a is the smallest superficial diameter and b is the largest superficial diameter). After 15 days of treatment, tumors were harvested from killed mice, snap-frozen in liquid nitrogen, and stored at −80 °C. Tumors tissue homogenates were lysed and separated by SDS-PAGE to examine the expression of STAT3 phosphorylation in vehicle- and 11-treated mice.

Six-week-old female mice, of Specified Pathogens Free (SPF) grade, were purchased from Qinglongshan Animal Breeding Ground (Nanjing, China). Mice were divided into four treatment (i.p.) groups consisting of five mice/group: 10, 20, 40 and 80 mg/kg of 11, and the animals were observed for abnormal behavior and mortality up to 2 weeks post treatment.

The experimental mice were cared and handled strictly according to obligations of the Animal Ethics Committee of China Pharmaceutical University and the National Institutes of Health (NIH) standard guidelines for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animal.
